00030 /*
00031   Scanner for constraint expressions. The scanner returns tokens for each of
00032   the relational and selection operators. It requires GNU flex version 2.5.2
00033   or newer.
00034 
00035   The scanner is not reentrant, but can share a name space with other
00036   scanners. 
00037 
00038    Note:
00039    1) The `defines' file expr.tab.h is built using `bison -d'.
00040    2) Define YY_DECL such that the scanner is called `exprlex'.
00041    3) When bison builds the expr.tab.h file, it uses `expr' instead of `yy'
00042    for variable name prefixes (e.g., yylval --> exprlval).
00043 
00044   jhrg 9/5/95
00045 */
00046 
00047 %{
00048 
00049 #include "config_dap.h"
00050 
00051 static char rcsid[] not_used = {"$Id$"};
00052 
00053 #include <string.h>
00054 #include <assert.h>
00055 
00056 #include <string>
00057 #if 0
00058 #include <SLList.h>
00059 #endif
00060 
00061 #define YY_DECL int exprlex YY_PROTO(( void ))
00062 
00063 #include "Error.h"
00064 #include "parser.h"
00065 #include "expr.h"
00066 #include "RValue.h"
00067 #include "expr.tab.h"
00068 #include "escaping.h"
00069 
00070 #if 0
00071 static void store_int32();
00072 static void store_float64();
00073 #endif
00074 static void store_id();
00075 static void store_str();
00076 static void store_op(int op);
00077 
00078 %}
00079 
00080 %option noyywrap
00081 %x quote
00082     
00083 /* In the DAS and DDS parsers I removed the INT and FLOAT lexemes. However,
00084    not having them here complicates parsing since you must check to see if a
00085    word is a number (like 2.3) or a variable called `2.3.' I'm assuming that
00086    people will always put some characters in variable names (e.g., they'll
00087    use `2300.7%20MHz' and not just `2300.7'). If that turns out to be a bad
00088    assumption, the we'll have to put more code in the parser to figure out
00089    what exactly each word is; is it a constant or a variable name. Time will
00090    tell. 10/31/2001 jhrg */
00091 
00092 NAN     [Nn][Aa][Nn]
00093 INF     [Ii][Nn][Ff]
00094 /* See das.lex for comments about the characters allowed in a WORD.
00095    10/31/2001 jhrg 
00096 
00097    I've added '*' to the set of characters in a WORD for both the DDS and DAS
00098    scanners, but not here because it'll conflict with the url dereference
00099    operator. 6/10/2002 jhrg
00100 */
00101 
00102 SCAN_WORD       [-+a-zA-Z0-9_/%.\\][-+a-zA-Z0-9_/%.\\#]*
00103 
00104 SCAN_EQUAL  =
00105 SCAN_NOT_EQUAL  !=
00106 SCAN_GREATER    >
00107 SCAN_GREATER_EQL >=
00108 SCAN_LESS   <
00109 SCAN_LESS_EQL   <=
00110 SCAN_REGEXP =~
00111 
00112 NEVER       [^\-+a-zA-Z0-9_/%.\\#:;,(){}[\]*&<>=~]
00113 
00114 %%
00115 
00116 "["             return (int)*yytext;
00117 "]"             return (int)*yytext;
00118 ":"             return (int)*yytext;
00119 "*"     return (int)*yytext;
00120 ","     return (int)*yytext;
00121 "&"     return (int)*yytext;
00122 "("     return (int)*yytext;
00123 ")"     return (int)*yytext;
00124 "{"     return (int)*yytext;
00125 "}"     return (int)*yytext;
00126 
00127 {SCAN_WORD} store_id(); return SCAN_WORD;
00128 
00129 {SCAN_EQUAL}    store_op(SCAN_EQUAL); return SCAN_EQUAL;
00130 {SCAN_NOT_EQUAL} store_op(SCAN_NOT_EQUAL); return SCAN_NOT_EQUAL;
00131 {SCAN_GREATER}  store_op(SCAN_GREATER); return SCAN_GREATER;
00132 {SCAN_GREATER_EQL} store_op(SCAN_GREATER_EQL); return SCAN_GREATER_EQL;
00133 {SCAN_LESS} store_op(SCAN_LESS); return SCAN_LESS;
00134 {SCAN_LESS_EQL} store_op(SCAN_LESS_EQL); return SCAN_LESS_EQL;
00135 {SCAN_REGEXP}   store_op(SCAN_REGEXP); return SCAN_REGEXP;
00136 
00137 [ \t\r\n]+
00138 <INITIAL><<EOF>> yy_init = 1; yyterminate();
00139 
00140 \"      BEGIN(quote); yymore();
00141 <quote>[^"\\]*  yymore(); /*"*/
00142 <quote>\\.  yymore();
00143 <quote>\"   { 
00144               BEGIN(INITIAL); 
00145                   store_str();
00146           return SCAN_STR;
00147                 }
00148 <quote><<EOF>>  {
00149                   char msg[256];
00150           sprintf(msg, "Unterminated quote\n");
00151           YY_FATAL_ERROR(msg);
00152                 }
00153 
00154 {NEVER}         {
00155                   if (yytext) { /* suppress msgs about `' chars */
00156                     fprintf(stderr, "Character `%c' is not", *yytext);
00157                     fprintf(stderr, " allowed and has been ignored\n");
00158           }
00159         }
00160 %%
00161 
00162 // Three glue routines for string scanning. These are not declared in the
00163 // header expr.tab.h nor is YY_BUFFER_STATE. Including these here allows them
00164 // to see the type definitions in lex.expr.c (where YY_BUFFER_STATE is
00165 // defined) and allows callers to declare them (since callers outside of this
00166 // file cannot declare the YY_BUFFER_STATE variable). Note that I changed the
00167 // name of the expr_scan_string function to expr_string because C++ cannot
00168 // distinguish by return type. 1/12/99 jhrg
00169 
00170 void *
00171 expr_string(const char *str)
00172 {
00173     return (void *)expr_scan_string(str);
00174 }
00175 
00176 void
00177 expr_switch_to_buffer(void *buf)
00178 {
00179     expr_switch_to_buffer((YY_BUFFER_STATE)buf);
00180 }
00181 
00182 void
00183 expr_delete_buffer(void *buf)
00184 {
00185     expr_delete_buffer((YY_BUFFER_STATE)buf);
00186 }
00187 
00188 // Note that since atoi() (or strtol()) does not care about signedness, this
00189 // will dump an unsigned value into a signed variable. However, if the value
00190 // is used in an unsigned context (i.e., with an operand that is of unsigned
00191 // type) then the signed value can be cast back to unsigned without losing
00192 // information.
00193 
00194 #if 0
00195 static void
00196 store_int32()
00197 {
00198     exprlval.val.type = dods_int32_c;
00199     exprlval.val.v.i = atoi(yytext);
00200 }
00201 
00202 static void
00203 store_float64()
00204 {
00205     exprlval.val.type = dods_float64_c;
00206     exprlval.val.v.f = atof(yytext);
00207 }
00208 #endif
00209 
00210 static void
00211 store_id()
00212 {
00213     strncpy(exprlval.id, dods2id(string(yytext)).c_str(), ID_MAX-1);
00214     exprlval.id[ID_MAX-1] = '\0';
00215 }
00216 
00217 static void
00218 store_str()
00219 {
00220     // transform %20 to a space. 7/11/2001 jhrg
00221     string *s = new string(dods2id(string(yytext)));  // XXX memory leak?
00222 
00223     if (*s->begin() == '\"' && *(s->end()-1) == '\"') {
00224     s->erase(s->begin());
00225     s->erase(s->end()-1);
00226     }
00227 
00228     exprlval.val.type = dods_str_c;
00229     exprlval.val.v.s = s;
00230 }
00231 
00232 static void
00233 store_op(int op)
00234 {
00235     exprlval.op = op;
00236 }

00255  * cases files were added on that branch (so they appear on the trunk for
00256  * the first time).
00257  *
00258  * Revision 1.23.4.7  2002/11/06 21:53:06  jimg
00259  * I changed the includes of Regex.h from <Regex.h> to "Regex.h". This means
00260  * make depend will include the header in the list of dependencies.
00261  *
00262  * Revision 1.23.4.6  2002/06/11 00:40:52  jimg
00263  * I added '*' to the set of characters allowed in a WORD in both the DAS
00264  * and DDS scanners. It's not allowed in the expr scanner because that
00265  * would cause conflicts with the URL dereference operator.
00266  *
00267  * Revision 1.25  2002/06/03 22:21:16  jimg
00268  * Merged with release-3-2-9
00269  *
00270  * Revision 1.23.4.5  2002/02/20 19:16:27  jimg
00271  * Changed the expression parser so that variable names may contain only
00272  * digits.
00273  *
00274  * Revision 1.23.4.4  2001/11/01 00:43:51  jimg
00275  * Fixes to the scanners and parsers so that dataset variable names may
00276  * start with digits. I've expanded the set of characters that may appear
00277  * in a variable name and made it so that all except `#' may appear at
00278  * the start. Some characters are not allowed in variables that appear in
00279  * a DDS or CE while they are allowed in the DAS. This makes it possible
00280  * to define containers with names like `COARDS:long_name.' Putting a colon
00281  * in a variable name makes the CE parser much more complex. Since the set
00282  * of characters that people want seems pretty limited (compared to the
00283  * complete ASCII set) I think this is an OK approach. If we have to open
00284  * up the expr.lex scanner completely, then we can but not without adding
00285  * lots of action clauses to teh parser. Note that colon is just an example,
00286  * there's a host of characters that are used in CEs that are not allowed
00287  * in IDs.
00288  *
00289  * Revision 1.24  2001/08/24 17:46:22  jimg
00290  * Resolved conflicts from the merge of release 3.2.6
00291  *
00292  * Revision 1.23.4.3  2001/08/16 17:26:20  edavis
00293  * Use "%option noyywrap" instead of defining yywrap() to return 1.
00294  *
00295  * Revision 1.23.4.2  2001/07/28 01:10:42  jimg
00296  * Some of the numeric type classes did not have copy ctors or operator=.
00297  * I added those where they were needed.
00298  * In every place where delete (or delete []) was called, I set the pointer
00299  * just deleted to zero. Thus if for some reason delete is called again
00300  * before new memory is allocated there won't be a mysterious crash. This is
00301  * just good form when using delete.
00302  * I added calls to www2id and id2www where appropriate. The DAP now handles
00303  * making sure that names are escaped and unescaped as needed. Connect is
00304  * set to handle CEs that contain names as they are in the dataset (see the
00305  * comments/Log there). Servers should not handle escaping or unescaping
00306  * characters on their own.
00307  *
00308  * Revision 1.23.4.1  2001/06/23 00:52:08  jimg
00309  * Normalized the definitions of ID (SCAN_ID), INT, FLOAT and NEVER so
00310  * that they are (more or less) the same in all the scanners. There are
00311  * one or two characters that differ (for example das.lex allows ( and )
00312  * in an ID while dds.lex, expr.lex and gse.lex don't) but the definitions
00313  * are essentially the same across the board.
00314  * Added `#' to the set of characeters allowed in an ID (bug 179).
00315  *
00316  * Revision 1.23  2000/08/31 23:44:16  jimg

00321  * (?) for UNIX clients that read from servers run on win32 machines (e.g.,
00322  * the Java-SQL server can be run on a win32 box).
